talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Home Affairs, in writing, on 12 May 2009:

item.para: What role, if any, did the Australian Federal Police or Australian Public Service have in dealing with the death that took place at Sydney Airport on 22 March 2009.
Were officers of the above services on site or on scene at the time of this incident, and what actions did they take then or subsequently.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The Australian Federal Police (AFP) provided a timely and comprehensive police response to multiple and simultaneous reports of a large disturbance occurring in Terminal Three of Sydney Airport on 22 March 2009, which resulted in the death of one male.
The AFP has provided all necessary assistance to the New South Wales Police Force which has primary responsibility for the ongoing investigation into the affray and associated death.

AFP officers were not directly within view of the incident when it was initiated however the first officers arrived on scene within one minute of being notified by a member of the public. Within seventeen minutes of the initial disturbance, nineteen AFP officers were on scene, to provide initial response, crime scene preservation, cordon and containment actions, public engagement and statement taking activities.

The AFP has formally handed over responsibility for the ongoing investigation to the New South Wales Police Force in accordance with the Memorandum of Understanding between the AFP and New South Wales Police for Cooperation in Relation to Incident Response, Crime and Security Issues at Sydney Kingsford Smith Airport (Sydney Airport).
A formal and independent review of the timeliness and appropriateness of the AFP first response was delivered on 7 April 2009 by Mr Roger Wilkins AO, Secretary of the Attorney-General’s Department.

The “Report of a Review of the AFP’s Response to an Incident at Sydney Airport on 22 March 2009”, concluded that the AFP response was undertaken in accordance with existing standards, procedures and protocols.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Home Affairs, in writing, on 12 May 2009:

item.para: How many conferences have been held and how many students have been hosted at the Australian Police College since its temporary relocation to the School of Artillery site at North Head, Sydney.
When did the College commence operations at the temporary site.
Is it still the Government’s intention to build a new college on the original site at Spring Cove, Sydney; if so, what is the current estimate of costs for this construction.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The Australian Institute of Police Management (AIPM) has conducted thirty Law Enforcement Leadership courses ranging from one to three weeks in duration, with 702 students attending these courses since its temporary relocation to the former School of Artillery site at North Head, Sydney.

The AIPM continues to conduct business operations from the Collins Beach site at North Head, Sydney and from July 2007 has temporarily relocated a portion of its business operations to the former School of Artillery.

The AIPM redevelopment proposal is being managed by the AFP and was approved by the NSW Minister for Planning on 20 March 2009. The redevelopment application has been referred to the Commonwealth for a determination, which is anticipated in June 2009. The total approved budget and current estimated cost for the AIPM redevelopment is $20.95 million, which is approved funding held over from previous years.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Home Affairs, in writing, on 13 May 2009:

quote.para: In respect of the Air Security Officers Program:

item.label: (a)
item.para: what was the number of “flying hours” (hours spent in the air) worked by Air Security Officers (ASOs) from (i) 1 February 2008 to 31 January 2009, (ii) 1 February 2007 to 31 January 2008; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: what other duties might ASOs perform when they are not in the air patrolling Australia’s domestic and international flights.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The number of “flying hours” worked by Air Security Officers (ASOs) is operationally sensitive information. It is standing policy not to disclose details regarding operational aspects of the ASO program.

item.label: (b)
item.para: In addition to ASO in-flight duties, ASOs undertake skills maintenance, administration, operational planning and intelligence gathering activities.
